question: For the reaction, <katex>$A\rightleftharpoons B$</katex> <katex>$E_{a}=50~kJ~mol^{-1}$</katex> and <katex>$\Delta H=-20kJ~mol^{-1}.$</katex> When a catalyst is added, <katex>$E_{a}$</katex> decreases by <katex>$10~kJ~mol^{-1}$</katex> What is the <katex>$E_{a}$</katex> for the backward reaction in the presence of catalyst? [cite: 351-352]
explanation: Catalyzed <katex>$E_a$</katex> (forward) = 50 - 10 = 40 kJ/mol. <katex>$\Delta H$</katex> is unchanged (-20 kJ/mol). <katex>$\Delta H = E_a(f) - E_a(b)$</katex>. -20 = 40 - <katex>$E_a(b)$</katex>. <katex>$E_a(b) = 60$</katex> kJ/mol. [cite: 353, 357]
